oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Basis for Selection of a Cardiac Glycoside for Dogs
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hamlin, Robert L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: cardiac glycoside
digitoxin
digoxin
comparative pharmacology
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Once a decision has been made that a cardiac glycoside is indicated for a dog, the veterinarian may select from one of two commonly-used compounds: Digitoxin or digoxin. Although a very few veterinarians prescribe ouabain or whole leaf digitalis, most opt for either digitoxin or digoxin. This paper shall describe certain features of the comparative pharmacology of these two glycosides in man and in dogs, and the reasons for selecting one over the other based upon, not pharmaco-dynamics (what the drug does to the body!), but on pharmacokinetics (what the body does to the drug!). A special consideration will be given to the pragmatic feature of how many tablets of each glycoside must be given dogs of various sizes.
